titleStmt.title: A commission vvith instructions and directions, granted by his Maiestie to the Master and Counsaile of the Court of Wards and Liueries for compounding for wards, ideots, and lunaticks, and giuen vnder his Highnesse great Seale of England the eleuenth day of December 1618.
titleStmt.author: England and Wales. Sovereign (1603-1625 : James I)
James I, King of England, 1566-1625.
Banbury, William Knollys, Earl of, 1547-1632.
England and Wales. Court of Wards and Liveries.

publicationStmt.publisher: Printed by Bonham Norton and Iohn Bill, printers to the Kings most excellent Maiestie,

notesStmt.note: The Master and Counsaile of the Court of Wards and Liveries = William Knollys, Earl of Banbury.
A considerably revised version of the commission issued 23 Feb. 1618.
The first leaf contains signature-mark A in part of a woodcut frame.
The text is found in two impositions; sheets may be mixed.
Reproduction of the original in the Henry E. Huntington Library and Art Gallery.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: A COMMISSION WITH INSTRVCTIONS AND DIRECTIONS, granted by his Maie≈øtie to the Ma≈øter and Coun≈øaile of the Court of Wards and Liueries, For compounding for Wards, Ideots, and Lunaticks, And giuen vnder His Highne≈ø≈øe great Seale of England The eleuenth day of December 1618.
LONDON, Printed by BONHAM NORTON and IOHN BILL, Printers to the Kings most Excellent Maie≈øtie. M.DC.XVIII.

figure.figDesc: royal blazon or coat of arms
figure.q: HONI SOIT QVI MAL Y PENSE

div.head: ¬∂ By the King.

opener.signed: IAMES, by the grace of GOD King of England, Scotland, France and Ireland, Defender of the Faith, &c.
opener.salute: To Our right tru≈øtie, and right welbeloued Councellour, WILLIAM Lord Knollys, Vi≈øcount Wallingford, Ma≈øter of Our Court of Wards and Liueries, And to Our tru≈øtie and wellbeloued the Councell of the ≈øame Court, And to the Ma≈øter and Councell of the ≈øaid Court for the time being, Greeting.

div.p:
WHEREAS Wee haue heretofore publi≈øhed ≈øeuerall Commi≈ø≈øions, with In≈øtructions and Directions to you Our Ma≈øter
and Councell of Our Court of Wards and Liueries, for compounding for Wards, Ideots and Lunatiques, now that time and experience haue produced the knowledge of ≈øundry defects, that otherwi≈øe could not ea≈øily haue been fore≈øeene, which are to bee ≈øupplied by explanation and addition to the ≈øame Our In≈øtructions, according to Our gracious purpo≈øe for the good of Our louing Subiects, & Our e≈øpeciall care for the true an≈øwering of Our Reuenues. And for≈øomuch as it doth appeare by common experience, in the cour≈øe which hath beene helde ≈øince the fir≈øt erection of Our Court of Wards and Liueries, That partly by the ≈ølackene≈ø≈øe of the Friends of the Wards, vpon the decea≈øe of the Parents or Ance≈øtours, who haue forborne to offer timely Compo≈øition, ≈øometimes with opinion, that no Tytle could be found for Vs, and ≈øomtimes with purpo≈øe to ≈øuppre≈ø≈øe the ≈øame, & partly by the ≈øuite of other men, the Cu≈øtodie of the bodies and lands of Our Wards, haue been committed to ≈øuch per≈øons, ≈øome for one
re≈øpect, ≈øome for another, as (notwith≈øtanding the care and prouidence of you the Ma≈øter and Councell of Our Court, to bind them in great Bonds and Couenants for the well educating of the Children, and pre≈øeruation of their Inheritance) haue been carele≈ø≈øe of their education, married ≈øome in meane places, committed wa≈øtes and ≈øpoyles vpon their Lands, and in the end haue exacted greater ≈øummes of money for the marriages of ≈øuch Wards, then they ought to haue done in rea≈øon and equity; notwith≈øtanding any their disbur≈øements what≈øoeuer for pa≈øsing or procuring the ≈øame.

And whereas al≈øo Wee haue bene informed by you the Ma≈øter of the ≈øaide Court, that by rea≈øon of the great difficulties that haue bene found by the Court, vpon ≈øight of Offices, and Surueyes only, to ≈øet downe Compo≈øitions for Ward≈øhips and Lea≈øes of Wards Lands, with ≈øuch equalitie and moderation betweene Vs, and Our Subiects, as were iu≈øt and rea≈øonable; and that through want of due information in
that behalfe, much of the profit that might haue bene rai≈øed for Vs, hath bene diuerted to diuers Sutors and Committees, who by ob≈øcuring the trueth of the Wards e≈øtate, and by mi≈øinforming of the Court therein, haue reaped greater profite, then was intended, if you could by ordinary meanes, haue come by the knowledge of their values; ≈øo as, both Wee haue receiued le≈ø≈øe then otherwi≈øe We ≈øhould haue done, and the Wards found little ea≈øe in many ca≈øes.

Wherefore, for the preuenting of the≈øe and the like inconueniences, and to the end that Our louing Subiects may ≈øtand a≈ø≈øured, that Wee de≈øire nothing more, then that their Children and their Lands; that ≈øhall fall vnto Vs by rea≈øon of Ward≈øhips, might after their decea≈øe, bee committed to their neere≈øt and tru≈øtie≈øt friends, or to ≈øuch as they, by Wil, or otherwi≈øe, commit the charge vnto, vpon ≈øuch valuable con≈øiderations, as are iu≈øt and rea≈øonable: And to the intent that the Parents and Ance≈øtours may depart in greater
peace, in hope of this Our gracious fauour; and their friendes may ≈øee their Children brought vp in pietie and learning, and may take ≈øuch care as is fit, for the pre≈øeruation of their inheritance, if they wil ≈øeeke the ≈øame in time, and by ≈øuch meanes as are fitte and conuenient; Wee haue thought good hereby to require you, the Ma≈øter and Councell of the ≈øaid Court for the time beeing, that in di≈øpo≈øing and committing of the cu≈øtodie of the Bodies and Lands of ≈øuch Our Wards, who≈øe Ance≈øtours are already decea≈øed, or ≈øhall die from and after the date of the≈øe pre≈øents, and of ≈øuch Ideots and Lunatiques, and their E≈øtates, as ≈øhall fall vnto Vs from hencefoorth, you ≈øhal ≈øtrictly and carefully ob≈øerue the≈øe Our Directions following.

FIRST, that no Direction for the finding of any Office, bee giuen for Ward≈øhip of the Body and Lands of any Ward, vntill the ende of one moneth next after the death of the Ance≈øtor of the Ward, but to the neere≈øt and tru≈øtie≈øt
friends of the Ward, or other per≈øons nominated by the Ance≈øtor in the Wards behalfe, who may in the meane time become Suitors for the ≈øame, among whom, choice may be made of the be≈øt and fitte≈øt: and if none of the Wards friends make petition by the end of the moneth, then it ≈øhall be lawfull for any other to petition, and to finde the Office for the ≈øaid Ward≈øhip.

ALSO, That no compo≈øition, agreement or promi≈øe of any Ward≈øhip, or Lea≈øe of Lands bee made, vntill the Office bee found, and then ≈øuch of the Friends to haue preferment, as tendered their Petitions within the moneth, they yeelding a rea≈øonable Compo≈øition; and in default of them, ≈øuch others as were or ≈øhall be Suitors, yeelding al≈øo a rea≈øonable Compo≈øition.

ALSO, You ≈øhall doe your be≈øt indeuours to informe your ≈øelues as perticularly as you may, by Commi≈ø≈øion, Suruey or otherwi≈øe, of the truth of the Wards E≈øtates, a≈øwell of his Inheritance, as of his Goods and Chattels, and of the E≈øtate of
the decea≈øed Ance≈øtor, and of all other due circum≈øtances con≈øiderable, to the ende the Compo≈øitions may bee ≈øuch as may ≈øtand both with Our rea≈øonable profit, and with the abilitie of the heires e≈øtate.

THAT all Petitions for Ward≈øhips, Ideots and Lunatiques, ≈øhalbe fir≈øt deliuered to the Clerke of the Court, by the Suitor him≈øelfe, and the Clerke of the Court is hereby directed to make entry of the ≈øame Petitions without any Fee, the very day of the deliuery of the ≈øame, and returne them to the Suitor, who ≈øhall afterward pre≈øent the ≈øame Petition openly at the Councell Table of the Court of Wards, there to be ordered by the Officers at their next ≈øitting.
THAT euery ≈øuch Petition doe expre≈ø≈øe the ≈øeuerall Counties, wherein the Ance≈øtors died ≈øei≈øed of Lands.

THAT all Petitioners that haue warrant to finde an Office, and appointed to attend at a certaine day, if after they finde no Office, nor doe not attend before the Officers for their Compo≈øition, at ≈øuch
time as was appointed, then they ≈øhall loo≈øe the benefit of their Petition, and their bond ≈øhalbe put in Proce≈ø≈øe, ≈øauing they ≈øhall be admitted to make their rea≈øonable excu≈øe in any of the fore≈øaid Ca≈øes.
THAT euery Feodary doe appoint ≈øome certaine per≈øon and place in London, whither the Court may ≈øend directions to bee conueyed to the Feodaries continually for Our ≈øeruice.

THAT euery Feodary at the end of euery Terme, attend the Clerke of the Court, and take notice and direction out of the Petitions entred with the ≈øaide Clerke, in what Counties Our Tenaunts died ≈øei≈øed of any Lands, and of the Lands of Idiots, and that the Feodaries accordingly ≈øend vp their Certificate of the be≈øt improued valew of all the ≈øame Lands, lying in their ≈øaid ≈øeuerall Counties, by the fir≈øt ≈øitting of the Officers the next Terme following.

THAT the Feodary doe make his Certificate by view or other ≈øpeciall information of the be≈øt improoued valew, with his
rea≈øons thereof priuately without giuing knowledge to the Suitor, or any for him of any valew intended by him to be certified, and without taking any Fee or Reward from the Suitor, or any for him for valewing the Lands or per≈øonall e≈øtate.

THAT the Feodaries do name in their Certificats, the Lands in order one after another, as they lye in order in the Office, and to ≈øet downe in the one Margent of their Certificats, the valew in the office, and in the other Margent the improoued valew certified to the Officers, and the ≈øame valuations to be di≈øtributed according to the e≈øtates found in the Office.

THAT the Feodarie doe certifie all Coppieholds, Lea≈øes, valew of woods, or other per≈øonall e≈øtate that commeth to the Ward, or any immediate po≈ø≈øibilitie of any e≈øtate of Lands, whereby his marriage may be improoued.

THAT the Feodary ≈øhall not mention in his Certificate, any thing omitted out of the office again≈øt the King to abate the Compo≈øition, but ≈øhall leaue the ≈øame to
be alledged by the Suitor to be allowed (if cau≈øe be) vpon proofe to be made thereof by them at the Compo≈øition.
THAT the E≈øcheator, and Feodary, and Commi≈ø≈øioners ≈øhall prouide, that Offices bee not confu≈øedly found, by ioyning diuers Mannors and Lands in one gro≈ø≈øe value together.

THAT the Certificates of the Feodarie bee deliuered by the fir≈øt ≈øitting of the Officers in euery Terme, to the Clerke of the Court, clo≈øe ≈øealed vp, and ≈øo to remaine with the Clerke vnopened, vntill the time of Compo≈øition: And if it be deliuered by the hands of a ≈øtranger, then he to deliuer it vpon oath, according to the v≈øuall cour≈øe of the Court in like ca≈øes, and to be brought by the Clerke vnopened, at the Officers ≈øitting there to be opened, and v≈øe to bee made of the ≈øame.

THAT the Feodaries doe find Offices at the be≈øt value that may appeare vpon ≈øearch of ancient Offices, or other Records; if there be no Record, then to be found by the Iurie, according to Euidence to bee giuen.

THAT no Office be found within the yeere after the death of the Ance≈øtor again≈øt Vs or a meane Tenure of Vs (not being Knights ≈øeruice) for any Ward within age, vntill the Feodary or E≈øcheator do fir≈øt acquaint the Court for further directions therein, which the Feodary is inioyned to doe with all conuenient expedition.

THAT euery Feodary and E≈øchetor, before the third Returne of euery Terme, ≈øhall certifie into the Court, a note of all Offices found in the vacation next before, and whether a Tenure be found for Vs in Capite or by Knights ≈øeruice, & the names of the Ance≈øtor and Heire, and his age.

THAT the Clerks of the Pettie Bagge, doe file and tran≈øcribe all Offices that bee brought to them, and not to reiect or ≈øuppre≈ø≈øe the ≈øame, and the like cour≈øe to bee v≈øed in the Exchequer with Offices that be returned into the Exchequer; and that all due Fees bee foorthwith di≈øcharged and payd vnto the Clerkes and Officers of the ≈øayd Courts: And if any per≈øon ≈øhall denie or neglect to pay any ≈øuch due Fees, then
vpon the petition of the ≈øayd Clerke to the Court of Wards, order ≈øhall bee taken for their ≈øatisfaction.
THAT no E≈øchetor ≈øhall inforce any man to ≈øhew his Euidence vnto him≈øelfe, neither ≈øhall hee haue any power to di≈øcharge the Subiects from finding their Offices.

THAT all Sales and Compo≈øitions for Ward≈øhips of the Bodies, and Lea≈øes of Lands, (except the ca≈øes of Concealements hereafter mentioned) and all Commitments of Ideots, and cu≈øtodie of their E≈øtates bee made by the Ma≈øter and Councell of the ≈øame Court, openly in the Councell Chamber of the Court of Wards, and by ≈øuch per≈øons as are authori≈øed by Statute in that behalfe. Neuerthele≈ø≈øe, the Surueyor of the Liueries, the Attourney of the Wards, Receiuer and Auditors, or any foure of them, without the Ma≈øter, may treate with any to bring the ≈øayd Ward≈øhips, and the Lea≈øes, and the Commitments of Ideots to a price, openly in the Councell Chamber of the Court of Wards,
and acquaint the Ma≈øter therewith; in who≈øe power it ≈øhall bee to allow of the ≈øame, according to the ≈øaid Statute.

THAT Lea≈øes of Wards Lands (except the ca≈øes of Concealements hereafter mentioned) be made with a ≈ømall or little Fine, and for the be≈øt improued yerely Rent that ≈øhall be offered, con≈øideration being had of all due cautions, as afore≈øayd.

THAT fellable Woods, and Fines of Copiholds of inheritance bee al≈øo rea≈øonably valued and demi≈øed with the Lands, for the be≈øt yeerely Rent, as afore≈øaid, with proui≈øion for fellable Woods, that the Le≈ø≈øees ≈øell them by fit portions.

THAT Fines of Copieholds for liues bee made and rai≈øed to Our v≈øe, when, and as often as the Court ≈øhall thinke good, by certaine particular Commi≈ø≈øioners, to bee appointed by the Ma≈øter and Councell of Our ≈øayd Court; which Commi≈ø≈øioners ≈øhall bee charged to make the be≈øt of ≈øuch Copieholds to bee granted, and truely to an≈øwere vnto Vs into Our Receipt of Our ≈øayd Court, all ≈øuch ≈øummes, without fraud
or couin, as by them ≈øhal haue bin receiued, due con≈øideration being had of their pains and expences, or el≈ø ‚Ä¢ the ≈øame to bee compounded for at the Councell chamber of the Court of Wards, as in other ca≈øes of compo≈øitions.
THAT the rate and ≈øumme agreed vpon by the Commi≈ø≈øioners for the compo≈øition of any Ward or Lea≈øe, do ≈øtand, and bee not abated in the compo≈øition, neither in the Fine nor Rent.

THAT no Ward≈øhips of the Body or Land (except the ca≈øes of concealements hereafter mentioned) ≈øhalbe giuen or granted to any per≈øon, or at his ≈øuit, by way of reward or benefit, but the be≈øt price & value that ≈øhalbe offered, ≈øhalbe taken to Our v≈øe; So alwayes as the neere≈øt and tru≈øtie≈øt Friends, or the per≈øons nominated by the Ance≈øtor (they ≈øeeking the ≈øame in time conuenient, as afore≈øayd, and making fit offer for it) bee preferred, and con≈øideration had of the Wardes E≈øtate, and of all due circum≈øtances con≈øiderable in ≈øuch Ca≈øes.

THAT no Fine for any concealed Ward≈øhip, or the Fine of the Lea≈øe of any Land be a≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed, but openly at the Councell Chamber of the Court of Wards, by the Ma≈øter and the Councell at their ≈øeuerall ≈øittings.
THAT no mittigation of any meane rates, valewes and forfeiture of marriage, Fines, debts or charges be di≈øcharged or abated, but by the Ma≈øter and Councell openly at their ≈øeuerall ≈øittings.

THAT not only euery Committee and Le≈ø≈øee, but euery A≈ø≈øignee of euery Committee or Le≈ø≈øee (except the Ca≈øes of Concealements hereafter mentioned) ≈øhall take the Oath, viz. &c. And for that purpo≈øe euery Committee, and Le≈ø≈øee, & A≈ø≈øignee, ≈øhall be ≈øworne whether he taketh it to his owne v≈øe, or to the v≈øe of any other, to the end they may both take the Oath.

AND furthermore, Wee doe hereby require and authori≈øe you, that you giue order, that euery per≈øon that ≈øhall pro≈øecute ≈øuch Compo≈øition for the cu≈øtodie of a Ward, Ideot, or Lunatique, or Lea≈øe of their
Land, or other e≈øtate (except the Ca≈øes of Concealements hereafter mentioned) ≈øhall before any grant of the body, or lea≈øe of the Lands, bee deliuered vnto him vnder the Scale of Our ≈øaid Court, take his corporall Oath in open Court, or by Commi≈ø≈øion (if the cau≈øe ≈øhall ≈øo require) before three Commi≈ø≈øioners at the lea≈øt, whereof one to be a Iu≈øtice of the Peace, to be certified and returned into the Court, before the deliuery of ≈øuch graunt or Lea≈øe, in maner and forme following, viz.

p.hi: J. A. B. doe ≈øweare, That neither I, nor any other to my knowledge, haue or hath giuen, or promi≈øed, procured or coÃÑ≈øented to giue or to be giuen any gift or reward, directly or indirectly, vnto any Officer or Officers of the Court of Wards and Liueries, or to any other per≈øon or per≈øons what≈øoeuer, for procuring any preferment to compound before an other, or for mitigation

in the price or payment in any Compo≈øition or Contract made, or to be made for the Ward≈øhip of the body of I. S. his Maiesties Ward, and the Lea≈øe of any the ≈øaide Wards Lands, or for the ≈øigning or di≈øpatching of any Grants of them, or any of them, or for the mitigatioÃÑ of the yerely valew of any of the Lands of the ≈øaid Ward (ordinary Fees onely excepted,) And that I will not giue, nor any with my con≈øent ≈øhall giue, or con≈øent to be giuen any gift or reward, directly or indirectly for the cau≈øes afore≈øaid, or any of them; And that I doe take the ≈øaide Ward≈øhip to the v≈øe of the ≈øaid Ward, and the ≈øaide Lea≈øe to the v≈øe of A. B. and not in tru≈øt for or to the v≈øe of any other per≈øon or per≈øons what≈øoeuer; So helpe mee God.

div.p: THAT e≈øpeciall choice be made of the Commi≈ø≈øioners that receiue the Oath in the Countrey, ≈øo that the Oath may bee truely and fully taken by the Committees, Le≈ø≈øees and A≈ø≈øignees, and the parties committing tru≈øt to any other.
THAT the Oath be taken by tho≈øe that are Committees or Le≈ø≈øees vpon neglect in hec verba.

p.hi: J. A. B. doe ≈øweare, that neither J, nor any other to my knowledge, or as I beleeue or haue heard, haue or hath taken any cour≈øe, or v≈øed any practi≈øe or combination directly or indirectly, by my ≈øelfe or by an other, with any per≈øon or per≈øons what≈øoeuer, to ≈øtay or hinder the pro≈øecution of, and for the Compo≈øition for the Ward≈øhip of the body of B. C. or the Lea≈øe of any of the ≈øaid Wards lands, with any purpo≈øe or intent what≈øoeuer,

that the ≈øaid Ward≈øhip and Lea≈øe, or either of them, by ≈øuch neglect and default of pro≈øecution, might come to mee, or to any other to my v≈øe, or by my meanes or procurement, or to my knowledge; So helpe me God.

div.p: THAT no Recu≈øant bee admitted to compound, or bee A≈ø≈øignee of any Ward of Bodie or Lands, or of Ideots.

THAT all tenders and continuances of Liueries, be onely made to the Surueyour of the Liueries, who is commanded to take an exact care of Our iu≈øt profits therin, Wee intending an account of him for that ≈øeruice.
THAT the Feodaries ≈øhall make Surueys vpon Liueries, in ca≈øes of ful age, a≈øwel as in ca≈øes within age; and both according to the rea≈øonable value, hauing re≈øpect to the improued value.

BVT touching Lunatiques, let no compo≈øition bee taken for the committing of them or their E≈øtates; but let ≈øuch care be
had therein, as they may bee freely committed to their be≈øt and neere≈øt friends, that can receiue no benefit by their death, and the Committees bound to an≈øwere, not onely the values found by Office, but the very iu≈øt value of their E≈øtates vpon accompts, for the benefit of ≈øuch Lunatique, (if hee recouer) or of his next Heire, Executors or Admini≈øtrators, due regard beeing had to the paines and charges of ≈øuch Committees, in keeping, maintaining gouerning, and curing of the ≈øaid di≈øtracted per≈øons.

THAT all the reuenues of the Wards Lands bee immediately payd into the Receipt of the Wards, vnto the Receiuer of the ≈øame Court, by the Farmors and Le≈ø≈øees them≈øelues, and ≈øhal not bee paid vnto the hands of any other (excepting ≈øuch Rents that bee vnder the value of tenne pounds a veere, which are appointed to be paid vnto the Feodaries.

THAT Petitions or demaunds for any allowance from vs exhibited by the Feodaries, or any other, for any ≈øeruice or di≈øbur≈øments
≈øhall not be granted or allowed vntill the ≈øame be both particularly examined and allowed by the Ma≈øter and Councell openly at their ≈øeuerall ≈øittings.

That the Receiuers account bee taken and declared euery yeere, according to the Statute of 32. Henr. Octaui, before the Ma≈øter of the Wards, Attourney, & one or both of the Auditors; and after the determination of the ≈øayd accompt, the Ma≈øter, Attourney, and the Auditor or Auditors, ≈øhall all of them ≈øet their hands to the Receiuers booke of Accompts, which is and ≈øhall be for the Receiuers charge and di≈øcharge, as the ca≈øe ≈øhall require.

THAT the Auditors doe ingro≈ø≈øe into Parchment all the ≈øaid Receiuers accounts, according to the expre≈ø≈øe time and direction of the Statute of 32. Henrici Octaui, and doe yeerely certifie and returne the ≈øame ≈øo ingro≈ø≈øed, with all the Warrants, Acquittances and Debenters into the Trea≈øurie of the Court of Wards, there to remaine as the Records of the Court, according to the Statute, and the ancient cour≈øe of the Court.

THAT all the accompts of the Feodaries be likewi≈øe declared and certified euery Hillary Terme, to the Ma≈øter and Councell of the Wards, openly at the ≈øittings of the Officers in the Councell Chamber, that the Court may knowe how the remaines vpon their accompts bee ≈øatisfied and paide, and their accompts to be accordingly returned into the Court, there to remaine.

AND becau≈øe Our purpo≈øe in this cour≈øe, which now is taken, is to rai≈øe with as little grieuance as may be to Our louing Subiects, that rea≈øonable benefit which ought to come vnto Vs, by the Marriages of Our Wards, and by their Lea≈øes of their Lands, whereof a great part hath been diuerted by Grants to Committees, and otherwi≈øe: Wee doe hereby declare, that it is not Our meaning to change the cour≈øe that hath been formerly held and v≈øed in finding Offices; nor to pre≈ø≈øe the rai≈øing or improouing of any values or Rates in any Inqui≈øitions, other then as afore≈øaid: Neither will Wee haue the Rents which
≈øhall bee re≈øerued vpon ≈øuch Lea≈øes, or any ≈øuch Certificats, Informations or In≈øtructions, as ≈øhall by any meanes be giuen or appeare of the valewes of ≈øuch Wards Lands or e≈øtates, to be tran≈øcribed, or tran≈ømitted to any other Court, Office, place or per≈øon; or admitted or v≈øed as Pre≈øident, euidence or inducement, to charge Our Subiects in any other payments now, or hereafter an≈øwerable vnto Vs, Our Heires or Succe≈ø≈øors, or for any other cau≈øe.

NEVERTHELES, Wee are well plea≈øed and contented, that if any Ward≈øhip, Lea≈øe of Land, Meane rates before or after full age, now be, or hereafter ≈øhal be concealed from Vs, and no Suite ≈øhall be made within three yeeres next after Our Tenants death, for ≈øuch Ward≈øhip or Lea≈øe; that in ≈øuch ca≈øe the Ma≈øter and Councell of the Court of Wards, openly in the Councel-chamber, as afore≈øaid, may admit any fit per≈øon what≈øoeuer, that ≈øhall make offer to di≈øcouer Our right ≈øo concealed, or ≈øought to be concealed and ≈øuppre≈ø≈øed, vpon good matter or proofe, ≈øhewed for Vs and approued
by the Court, to pro≈øecute the finding of an Office, and to pa≈ø≈øe the ≈øaide Ward≈øhip, lea≈øe or Meane rates, without re≈øtraining or binding the ≈øaid Court, or the partie pro≈øecuting, according to the Directions aboue mentioned, but that the Ma≈øter and Councel of the ≈øaid Court, may openly in the councel-Chamber, as afor≈øaid, according to the parties trauaile, expen≈øes, aduenture and ≈øeruice done vnto Vs, reward him, by granting ≈øuch Ward≈øhip, Lea≈øe, or Meane rates, in ≈øuch ≈øort as others may be encouraged to employ them≈øelues in the like Seruice; And all deuices and practi≈øes to deceiue and defraud Vs of Our due and iu≈øt Right, be better preuented; Any thing in the≈øe our In≈øtructions or Directions to the contrary notwith≈øtanding.

PROVIDED alwayes, and Wee doe hereby declare it to be Our will and plea≈øure, that where it ≈øhall appeare to you, that neither Wee nor Our Progenitors, haue enioyed any benefit by Ward≈øhip, Liuery, Primer ≈øei≈øen, Reliefe, Re≈øpect of Homage, Fines or Meane Rates of any Lands
within the ≈øpace of three≈øcore yeeres la≈øt pa≈øt, where ≈øuch benefite ought to haue come to the Crowne, if ≈øuch Tenure had bene acknowledged: In ≈øuch ca≈øes We are plea≈øed to giue power and authoritie to you Our Ma≈øter and Councell of Our Court, openly in the councel-Chamber, as afore≈øaid, to remit and relea≈øe all ≈øuch Benefit and profit, as haue or ought to haue accrued vnto Vs, or to Our Progenitors, by rea≈øon of any ≈øuch Tenure, allowing to ≈øuch per≈øons as haue pro≈øecuted in Our behalfe, ≈øuch part thereof as ≈øhall ≈øeeme good in your di≈øcretion, not exceeding a thirde part of the whole, as the ≈øame ≈øhalbe found by inqui≈øition; Sauing to Vs, Our Heires and Succe≈ø≈øours, the right and inheritance of Our Tenures; And ≈øauing Our Prerogatiue, and the benefit and profit of ≈øuch Tenures of Vs, or Our Progenitors, as doe expre≈øly appeare by matter of Record; And al≈øo ≈øuch as haue bene created, or otherwi≈øe come vnto Vs within the ≈øame time of three≈øcore yeeres.

AND now that We haue ≈øo ≈øufficiently directed you, as Wee make little doubt but you will bee carefull of Our profit in the execution of your places; So neuerthele≈ø≈øe, Wee let you know hereby, that ≈øeeing Our owne iudgement tells Vs, that there may fall into your con≈øiderations many circum≈øtances, which mu≈øt guide you in a≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øing the Fines for the marriages of Our Wards, and Renting of their Lands; ≈øome ari≈øing either out of the broken e≈øtate of the decea≈øed, want of proui≈øion for his Wife, his great charge of children vnprouided for, infirmitie or tenderne≈ø≈øe of the Heire, vncertainty of the Title, or greatne≈ø≈øe of incumbrance vpon the Land, ≈øo as ≈øome Heire, that may in re≈øpect of his degree, blood, or liuing, in opinion of the world be iudged to de≈øerue a greater Rent or Fine, then ≈øome other per≈øons more ob≈øcure may, yet in regard of the cau≈øes aboue mentioned, or ≈øome other of like ≈øort, le≈ø≈øe fit to haue any greater charge laid vpon him: Wee doe therefore, notwith≈øtanding
any thing contained in the≈øe Our In≈øtructions, giue you full libertie, that as the≈øe, or any other the like con≈øiderations, ≈øhall offer them≈øelues vnto you, you may v≈øe that good di≈øcretion and con≈øcience which is fit, openly in the Councell chamber, as afore≈øaid, in mittigating or abating the Fines or Rents vpon the ≈øaid Grants or Lea≈øes, to the reliefe of ≈øuch nece≈ø≈øities; So alwayes as care be taken, that by any ≈øuch preten≈øes, that profit which ≈øhould accrue vnto Vs, be not diuerted to any others that ≈øhall ≈øeeke to drawe to them≈øelues a priuate benefit out of this Our gracious care and con≈øideration. And Our will and plea≈øure is, and Wee doe hereby direct and authori≈øe you the Ma≈øter and Councell of the ≈øayd Court, and the Ma≈øter and Councell of the ≈øame for the time beeing, that with the aduice of Our Iudges, A≈ø≈øi≈øtants of Our ≈øayd Court, you diligently examine, ≈øearch out, and reforme all fraudulent deuices and practi≈øes, deui≈øed or to be deui≈øed and put in vre, to deceiue and defeate
Vs of Our Ward≈øhips, or Lea≈øes of Our Wards Lands, or of any due or iu≈øt benefit belonging vnto Vs, by rea≈øon of Our Tenures.

AND la≈øtly, that the Ma≈øter of the Wardes, Surueyour, Attourney, Receiuer, Auditors, Clerke of the Court, and his Deputie, the Clerke of the Liueries and his Deputie, and all the Feodaries, and the Ma≈øters Secretarie, and all other Officers, and per≈øons imployed in his Maie≈øties Reuenue of the Wards, ≈øhall take an expre≈ø≈øe oath, openly in the Councell chamber of the Court of Wardes, in manner and forme following.

I, A. B. doe ≈øweare, that neither I, nor any other per≈øon for me by my appointment, knowledge or con≈øent, ≈øhall take or receiue of any per≈øon, any gift or reward directly or indirectly, for any Compo≈øition or preferment,
or cau≈øing any per≈øon or per≈øons to be preferred to compound before another, or to haue any mittigation in the price, or payment in any Compo≈øition or contract, at any time hereafter to bee made for the Ward≈øhip of the bodie, or Lea≈øe of the Lands of any his Maiesties Wards, or for the cu≈øtody of any his Maie≈øties Ideots, or Lunatikes, or their Lands, Goods or Chattels, or for the ≈øigning or di≈øpatching of any Warrant for any Grant of them or any of them, excepting ordinary Fees: So helpe mee God. In witne≈ø≈øe whereof Wee haue cau≈øed the≈øe Our Letters to bee made Patents.

Witne≈ø≈øe Our≈øelfe at We≈øtmin≈øter
the eleuenth day of December, in the ≈øixteenth yeere of Our Reigne of England, France and Ireland, and of Scotland the two and fiftieth.
